Topic.Title: Ebay Seller's Beware, This Could Happen To You...

Message.Msg: It does not matter how CLEARLY your auction stes that it is the buyers responsibility for insurance. It is the sellers responsibility to make sure that an item gets in the buyers hands, and in the condition described in the auction. You are the one who should've purchased the insurance. 1) Did the buyer claim that they never received the coin? Did you mail the coin with delivery confirmation? Delivery confirmation is your proof that the item arrived at its destination. 2) How much did the coin sell for? If it was more than $250 then signature confirmation is mandatory by Ebay. Again that would be your proof of delivery. The issue here is not with Ebay. It is with you, the seller. It is quite obvious that you have alot to learn as a seller.

Topic.Title: Ebay Seller's Beware, This Could Happen To You...

Message.Msg: Actually, not to agree with either of you but he is correct. It is a merchants responsibility to get the merchandise into the hands of the buyer regardless of if they're selling on eBay, Amazon or their own website. It's just good business ethics. If a merchant is accepting Paypal, you ALWAYS have to use Delivery Confirmation and signature confirmation on orders over $250. By using DC, if the tracking shows as delivered, the buyer has no recourse. Why on earth anybody who accepts Paypal doesn't print shipping labels through Paypal is beyond me, unless you like waiting in line at the post office to pay more for postage? I'm no Paypal fan by any means but it's really no big deal to meet their expectations and in all honesty, following their rules actually helped streamline my business.

Message.Title: Alibaba will end up taking most of the market share
